results.title: Shabbat Is a Salve, and a Scene
results.abstract: After pandemic separation and a recent surge in antisemitism, more young people — Jewish and not — seem to be celebrating the sabbath.

media.caption: The designer Susan Korn of Susan Alexandra, right, hosted a Shabbat dinner on Nov. 10. “We are all trying to figure out how to be Jews in the 21st century,” said Rabbi Matt Green, who led the blessings. “And this is it.”

results.title: They’re All Good Dogs, and It Has Nothing to Do With Their Breed
results.abstract: Retrievers that don’t retrieve and Papillons that point are all possible because the genes that shape dog behavior predate modern breeding that focuses on appearance, researchers find.

media.caption: On average, a dog’s breed only accounts for about 9 percent of the variations in any given dog’s behavior, according to the study.
media.copyright: Amir Hamja for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Cats;Pets;Animal Behavior;Animal Cognition;Research;your-feed-science;Animal Cognition (Journal)
results.title: Your Cat Might Not Be Ignoring You When You Speak
results.abstract: Cats have a reputation for being aloof, but a new study has found that their relationships with their owners may be stronger than we thought.

media.caption: Cats are often seen as aloof. But in a new study, they were not ignoring their owners, but instead “their reactions were very subtle,” the lead author of the study said.
